title: Mexican Strawberry Water (Agua de Fresa) Recipe
description: This strawberry water drink garnished with lime and mint leaves is easy to make in a blender with strawberries, sugar, and water for a refreshing treat.
body: ​ Skip to content Allrecipes Search Please fill out this field. Search the site Please fill out this field. About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines Latin American Mexican Mexican Strawberry Water (Agua de Fresa) 4.6 (94) 73 Reviews 24 Photos This strawberry water is extremely flavorful and refreshing, especially when fresh strawberries are in season. Fresh fruit waters made with crushed or blended fruit, called aguas de frutas in Spanish, are a common and popular drink all over Mexico. Submitted by Olivia Updated on March 31, 2025 Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 24 24 24 24 Prep Time: 25 mins Additional Time: 4 hrs Total Time: 4 hrs 25 mins Servings: 10 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 10 servings 4 cups strawberries, sliced 1 cup white sugar 8 cups cold water, divided 5 cups ice for serving, or as needed 1 lime, cut into 8 wedges 8 fresh mint sprigs Directions Gather all ingredients. Grant Webster / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Mix together strawberries, sugar, and 1 cup cold water in a medium bowl. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place in the refrigerator for 4 hours. Grant Webster / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Pour chilled strawberry mixture into a blender. Blend on high until smooth. Grant Webster / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Pour through a wire mesh strainer set over a large bowl; discard pulp and seeds. Grant Webster / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Stir remaining 7 cups cold water into strawberry juice until aqua de fresa is well combined. Grant Webster / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Fill glasses with ice. Pour aqua de fresa over ice. Garnish each serving with lime wedges and mint leaves. Grant Webster / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco Recipe Tip If not serving immediately, place strawberry water (aqua de fresa) in the refrigerator for several hours to chill. I Made It Print 214 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Mexican Strawberry Water (Agua de Fresa) 01 of 24 Photo by  Grant Webster / Food Stylist: Addelyn Evans / Prop Stylist: Gabriel Greco 02 of 24 Photo by  Jay 04/19/2021 03 of 24 Photo by  Vivienne 03/03/2020 04 of 24 Photo by  Mark Ghobrial 10/15/2019 05 of 24 Photo by  Cynthia Kolman 05/26/2018 Easy to make and very good! 06 of 24 Photo by  lutzflcat 05/11/2018 5.11.18 No artificial flavoring here, just sweet, ripe strawberries. Very nice! 07 of 24 Photo by  Tammy Lynn 05/06/2018 I liked this more than I thought I would. It's especially a great use for strawberries that are starting to get a little old. I think I could cut back on the sugar. I will make it again. 08 of 24 Photo by  arijab 06/21/2016 09 of 24 Photo by  Moji0256 05/30/2016 10 of 24 Photo by  Lacey 05/07/2016 1 2 3 Next You’ll Also Love Strawberry Basil Margarita 55 Ratings Watermelon Agua Fresca 86 Ratings Classic Frozen Strawberry Margarita 17 Ratings Spinach Strawberry Agua Fresca 4 Ratings Strawberry-Limeade Agua Fresca 2 Ratings Pepper-Mint Limeade 30 Ratings Horchata 552 Ratings Chef John's Watermelon Agua Fresca 42 Ratings Strawberry Beer Margaritas 9 Ratings Peach Sangria 11 Ratings Margaritas on the Rocks 321 Ratings Agua Fresca de Pepino (Cucumber Limeade) 37 Ratings Mama D's Very Berry Margaritas 5 Ratings Heavenly Honeydew Juice 5 Ratings Ultimate Frozen Strawberry Margarita 405 Ratings Spicy Watermelon Margarita 2 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family.
